content: How can I help you today?

I’ve been really struggling to sleep. It feels like my mind is just racing all the time, and I can’t seem to shut it off. I’m starting to feel stuck, and I don’t know what to do about it. My partner suggested I reach out for help, so here I am.

Thank you for sharing that—it sounds like getting sleep has become quite challenging for you lately, and it’s really weighing on you. It takes a lot of strength to open up and seek help, so it’s great that you’re here. Can you share a little more about what’s been on your mind or what’s contributing to that racing feeling?

I've been really stressed about work. I'm worried that I might get fired, especially with everything going on in the economy. If that happens, I don’t know how I’ll take care of my family or pay the bills. It’s just all I can think about when I try to go to sleep, and the thoughts spiral.

It sounds like work stress and the uncertainty about the future have been overwhelming for you, especially given your concerns about providing for your family. Those kinds of worries can make it hard to shut your mind off, especially when you're trying to rest. It’s clear that you deeply care about your family, and that responsibility weighs heavily. What’s been helping you get through these tough moments so far, even just a little?

Honestly, not much has really been helping. I end up scrolling on my phone to distract myself, but I know it just makes things worse because it keeps me awake even longer. I’ve tried to just lie there and calm down, but the thoughts keep coming. It feels like there's no escape from it.

That sounds exhausting, trying to quiet your thoughts and finding that distractions, even though they’re comforting in the moment, leave you feeling more stuck afterward. It sounds like you're really longing for peace of mind and restful sleep but feel trapped in a cycle that's hard to break. What would it mean for you to feel less stuck, even just a little bit?

I think feeling less stuck would mean being able to clear my mind at night so I can actually sleep and feel rested. Maybe it would mean feeling less overwhelmed by all the stress at work and not worrying so much about the worst-case scenarios. But honestly, it feels so far out of reach right now that I don't even know where to start.

It sounds like you're craving both physical rest and mental relief from the stress you've been carrying—being able to sleep, feel recharged, and manage those overwhelming worries without the weight dragging you down. It's understandable that starting feels difficult when it all seems so daunting. What do you think has made it feel out of reach for you so far?

I think it just feels out of reach because my mind doesn’t stop. Even when I try to relax, the stress just seems to take over. And honestly, I'm not sure I believe anything will work right now, so I don’t even know if it’s worth trying.  It’s like this has just become my normal.

It sounds like the constant stress has made it hard to believe things could be different, and it’s even starting to feel like this is just the way life is now. That’s such a heavy place to be—feeling stuck and not sure if trying would make a difference. But the fact that you’ve reached out today shows that some part of you is still looking for a way forward. What would it mean for you to believe that even small changes might help?

I think it would feel hopeful, but it’s hard to imagine right now. It’s like I want things to get better, but I also don’t want to try and then be disappointed if nothing changes. I guess I just don’t know how to take that first step.

It sounds like you’re carrying this mix of hope and hesitation—wanting things to change but also feeling unsure about taking a step forward and risking disappointment. That’s a tough balance to manage, especially when you’ve been feeling stuck for some time. What would taking that first step look like for you, even if it’s something small?

I guess a small step could be trying to put my phone down earlier, even though I know it’ll be hard. Maybe I could try something else to distract myself, like reading or something calm, but I’m not sure if that would even help. It’s just hard to motivate myself when I feel so stuck.

That sounds like a thoughtful first step—choosing something calming, like reading, as a different way to distract yourself before bed. It’s understandable that when you’re feeling stuck, it’s hard to find the motivation to try something new, especially if you’re unsure how much it will help. What would make it feel worthwhile to give it a try, even just once?

Maybe if I remind myself that I’m doing this for my family and to feel better for them, it could make it feel more worthwhile. I want to be more present with them and not so drained all the time. Thinking about them might help me push past how stuck I feel, at least for a little while.

It’s clear that your family is a big source of motivation for you, and focusing on how this could help you be more present and energized for them sounds like a meaningful way to reconnect with that motivation. Even when you feel stuck, reminding yourself of what matters most to you might help you take that first step. How do you feel about starting with something small today or tonight?

I think I can try. I'll aim to put my phone down earlier tonight and maybe grab a book instead. It might not work right away, but I can at least give it a shot. I want to do better for my family, even if it’s just taking one small step to start.

That’s a really positive step forward—making a small change like putting your phone down and trying something calmer, even when it feels hard, shows how much you care about moving forward for your family and yourself. It might not happen all at once, but small steps can build momentum over time. Is there anything else you’d like to talk about today before wrapping up?
I think I'm okay to end the conversation. Thank you for speaking about this with me—it feels good to have taken a small step forward.
